title: Low Taxes Drive Up Luxury House Prices in South Florida
text:
In South Florida, the luxury single-family home market is booming, driven by buyers migrating from high-tax states, according to market reports released Thursday.



“The Florida real estate migration due to SALT (state and local taxes) seems to be from the top down, and single-family sales are benefiting from flight capital leaving the Northeast,” said Jonathan Miller, chief executive of appraisal firm Miller Samuel and author of Douglas Elliman’s report.



More: For Plant Lovers, an Ideal Abode in London

Florida benefits from famously low state, local and property taxes.



But the Sunshine State became even more appealing to buyers after last year’s rewritten tax law, which capped the amount of mortgage interest tax payers could write off at $750,000, down from $1 million, and caused tax bills to surge for high earners in states with high income taxes.



In Miami Beach, luxury house prices hit a new record high, according to Douglas Elliman.



The median sale price for luxury single-family homes—defined by the brokerage as the top 10% of the market—rose 17.1% to $13 million in the third quarter compared to the same time a year ago, the report said.



A little further north in Palm Beach, the luxury market saw median prices hit a new record after skyrocketing 229.5% to $16.47 million, according to Douglas Elliman. The data didn’t differentiate between luxury single-family homes and luxury condo prices.

The numbers were pushed so high by some notable super-prime sales, according to another report released Thursday from Corcoran.



They included the $99.13 million sale of an oceanfront mansion by billionaire businessman and former owner of the Los Angeles Dodgers baseball team Frank McCourt. The house was reportedly bought by hedge fund billionaire Ken Griffin.



“We are seeing high-net-worth buyers coming in early in what is anticipated to be a long period of rising property values, specifically because of SALT,” Mr. Miller said.



In Fort Lauderdale, the median sale price for luxury single-family homes rose 30% to $2.1 million in the third quarter, according to Douglas Elliman.



Prices in Fort Lauderdale were skewed higher by a surge in sales of larger sized homes, the report said. The average square footage of luxury homes sold in the third quarter in the city was 4,741, a 15.3% increase from the same time last year.



Elsewhere along the coast, Boca Raton saw its median sales price for luxury single-family homes increase 33% to $2.2 million. In the village of Wellington, they jumped 66.7% to $1.42 million and in Coral Gables median prices were up 10.6% to $3.5 million.
